ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course taught what is expected in Calc II. It did not go much beyond that.
This course covered Integration, Infinite sums and series, polar area and coordinates, area between two curves, volumes of revolved shapes, and other topics you'd find in a Calc II course.

I learned practical applications of math in the world of areas and volumes.

I additionally learned new methods of integration.

I thought the course did a great job at covering a breadth of topics in integration. While I did take BC in high school the course was a great refresher and included topics and advanced techniques of integration that I did not learn in high school
Learning from a textbook, briefing myself on topics before class, working on problem sets.
You learn Math, its really that simple. If you like it, you like it if you dont, you dont.
I learned to use quantitative reasoning and application of integral calculus to answer real life problems such as areas and volumes of specific functions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this course was its consistent use of the textbook. This helped facilitate better learning. The weakness was that lecture did not always match the intensity of problem type that was seen on the exams.
Course moved very fast, exams are brutal.

I severely struggled with comprehending the curriculum, and the speed at which I would comprehend the material added struggle to my overall performance in the course. However, through the struggle I feel like I learned a great deal more.
Great course overall but heavily dependent on teaching style. There's a lack of standardization.

strengths are a well organized umbrella canvas site with very helpful "explores" that introduce the material and give students a chance to start to understand the material before class. Also lots of peer tutor office hours and availability to work with students. I wish there had been more interaction in the classroom, both with the professor and with other students (like working in groups on problems).

Strengths - I enjoyed the explorations and concept checks, even if they were a little tedious at times. The problem sets were 11 problems each week, not too much and not too little. Weaknesses - I did not enjoy the Calculus Story module included in the course, as it was not applicable to me as someone who was taking this class for the QR credit and do not expect to go into STEM.
I think there are certain concepts that could be easily taught, such as Simpson's Rule and the Root Test, that could be taught. Focusing on shells and Riemann sums at this level seem pointless.

The professor was great at explaining the materials and the psets really helped solidify my understanding. However, the quizzes before class sometimes left me really confused. It might be better to have a post class quiz instead.

From what I've heard and experienced through speaking to students in other classes, the experience for Math 115 varies extremely widely depending on section. I think that disparity might be improved by streamlining curriculum and teaching methods between TAs.

Though it was a challenging calculus course that I did learn a lot in, this course was not very engaging. It had no connection to anything outside the classrooms, and felt very "high-school". I think it would have been helpful to have the teaching broken from just the instructor speaking in front of the black board each day to maybe doing an activity/group work/discussion etc!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, I would not recommend this course to another student unless it is required for their major. I really enjoyed the high school equivalent of this course, Calc BC. This course, however, did not facilitate learning in the same way. I think part of the issue was that, being taught by a graduate student, there was a lack of connection with the professor. A huge part of my positive experience with a similar version of this content was the fact that the instructor was more engaging and also encouraged more group work/learning from peers versus always lecturing.
Only if you need this course. If you took Calc II (BC) in high school, be prepared to put more work in. This course is very much more on the theoretical side than the "solve problems" side.

I would recommend this course to another student. 

The course is a pre-requisite for a majority of majors, but is extremely beneficial.
Yes. But only if you need it as a prerequisite
Lets be real, this is a stepping stone course. Dont take it if you dont need to, unless you just really like math for maths sake.
Unless you're a math major, no need to take this course. You can fulfill QR credits through easier math courses.
I would recommend this course to other students because the foundations of integral calculus were well taught in a logical way.
Yes--it's a pretty good introductory course for calc.
NO!
